title: Connection Error
body:
Hoping anyone with knowledge of this kind of issue can chime in, I'm currently living in the western U.S.A. trying to connect to Oceania to play with my Australian friends. But recently, I'm inexplicably unable to connect to the server. I am able to authenticate and the client tries to log me in, but I wind up with a generic connection error message and the window closes when I click OK.

I've even submitted a ticket to riot support for troubleshoot help and we ran through every last thing, and nothing seems to have fixed it. It's nothing in my computer settings, it's nothing wrong with my install, I've power cycled the router/modem I have, I don't know what else to do.

replies.body:
>It's nothing in my computer settings

Unless you're the developer of the language of the engine used to make the OS and are familiar with everything in between, there's no way you can know this for certain.

>I've power cycled the router/modem I have

Have you tried using another router/modem?

If you're on a wireless connection, switch to testing on a wired one. Then, look over [this page](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664) (relevant to your OS, of course). Is that everything the red bots tried to get you to do?

I'm using a wired connection. This issue happens on all computers in my home, which is why I assumed that computer settings have nothing to do with it. I can factory install windows then put league on first thing, get a connection, and this issue will still happen. Hence the narrowing of it down to my ISP/Router. I have not tried using a different router/modem as I do not have spares, or the know how to switch them, the ISP would have to come to my physical location while I troubleshooted through all this.

>This issue happens on all computers in my home, which is why I assumed that computer settings have nothing to do with it.

But what if all your computers have the same faulty configuration? League can be run on more than one OS, and it's possible that there's a setting you just haven't seen/changed on Windows across all your devices. Also, reinstalling won't indicate to you if it's a config problem or not, *because if the problem is with the default settings...*

Morally incorrect, however. Programmers should make their programs run without requiring the user to change their personal settings. And in the rare case that it's absolutely required (like a whole environment or a server program), then it should be made crystal clear that this needs to be done before the program is installed.

Getting a bit off-topic...

>I have not tried using a different router/modem as I do not have spares, or the know how to switch them

Nah, that's ok. You should be able to find a fix without going to that extreme, if your connection is still working for other services. It just would have been handy. :P

Try lowering your internet security. Sounds insane, but sometimes it prevents a video-game (sometimes considered **the purest form of malicious software** to certain anti-virus softwares) from connecting to the internet. You can do this by disabling your firewall and anti-virus (if you're only testing out just this game, and not anything else like browsing the internet or streaming, then you're pretty safe) and then running the game. If that still fails, then you can try uninstalling those security measures (some like to actually edit system configurations, and revert them when they leave, or will still run in the background even if you've disabled it), but just make sure you have a way of getting them back (especially if they're paid software).

To go even further, go to your Internet Options (accessible from the Control Panel), reset all the settings to their default if you've changed them, and then set the security for the Internet from whatever it is to Low. Or the lowest available, if it's been limited on your computer. If you do that, tell me which level it is so I can see what's still activated.

Sorry for that wall of text, but if you're stuck with nothing to do because you can't play then I guess I just did you a favour, albeit a boring one.

Best of luck!
